Playstyle: Idle / Clicker RPG
Time vibe: Chill check-ins, low pressure

Firestone has become my ‚Äúcoffee break‚Äù game. Set up your squad, stack upgrades, and let the numbers climb while you do life. When you pop back in, there‚Äôs always a couple meaningful clicks‚Äîpromote a hero, nudge a build, grab rewards‚Äîand you‚Äôre out again. Exactly the cadence I want.

The art‚Äôs great‚Äîclean, colorful, and readable‚Äîso it feels good to watch your team churn through enemies without a cluttered screen. Progression feels steady, with regular goals that don‚Äôt demand a second job.

Guilds add a nice social layer without pressure. I‚Äôm running Hillside Hunters (Level 15) and the light co-op targets give me a reason to log in, say hi, and keep pushing.

Pros

Perfect ‚Äúset it and forget it‚Äù loop

Attractive, readable art and UI

Steady drip of upgrades/goals

Chill guild play (shoutout Hillside Hunters!)

Cons

Lots of menus as you progress

Not for people who want deep, hands-on combat

If you want something relaxing that rewards short, regular check-ins, Firestone nails it.

Mechanically, this is an interesting idle/clicker (heavy on the idle) game that can be a decent little comfort game (number go up, yay). It has a decent pavlovian reward scheme and can supply dopamine reliably. There is enough to do when active, and progress is made even when not playing the game. The mechanics and optimization paths are poorly documented, and the wiki is less than useful, but there are some guides (shout out to Aurora's complete guide). The art is mediocre mobile-game / greasy casino slots style poo, the sounds and music are pretty mediocre (and if you mute them all, it sometimes "forgets" when milestone notifications happen...), but it's easy to run, doesn't crash, and just works. 

That said, it has an extremely predatory pay to win (P2W) model and severely punishes free to play (F2P) players. The difference in progress between someone spending zero dollars and someone spending even 10 dollars is *weeks* of progress (which due to the exponential nature of this game, just gets worse and worse over time). The friction is bad enough, and the reward so massive, that you pretty much have to spend 10 dollars minimum (two of the starter bundles are massive, permanent progress boosters). 

If you have good self-control and can limit your P2W impulses, it's a decent relaxation dopamine drip for around 10 bucks. If you don't have good self-control, and are at all influenced by P2W tactics - this one is *extremely good at roping you in*, avoid it at all costs.

I‚Äôve played Firestone for over 150 hours now, and I wanted to share my thoughts for anyone who might be on the fence.

When I first started playing, I honestly didn‚Äôt know what to make of it. The game felt a bit overwhelming. There were a lot of systems thrown at me right away, and I wasn‚Äôt really sure what I was supposed to be focusing on. Progress felt slow, and I couldn‚Äôt tell if I was doing things ‚Äúright.‚Äù I actually considered dropping it a few times early on.

But I stuck with it, and I‚Äôm glad I did. Over time, things started to make more sense. The mechanics, while a bit confusing at first, gradually became clear. Once you understand how the different systems interact things like team synergy, gear upgrades, talents, and the value of idle rewards, the game really opens up. There‚Äôs a surprising amount of depth here for an idle RPG.

What I enjoy most is that it respects your time. You can check in a few times a day, make your upgrades, tweak your lineup, and feel like you‚Äôve made meaningful progress. There‚Äôs also enough content to keep you engaged for the long haul ‚Äî events, guilds, multiple progression paths, and a steady drip of new features from the developers. It always feels like there‚Äôs something to work toward.

It‚Äôs not perfect, of course. The early game could use a bit more onboarding or guidance, and I imagine some players bounce off before they really get to see what the game has to offer. But if you‚Äôre patient, and you enjoy idle games that reward long-term planning and incremental improvement, Firestone is definitely worth your time.

I'm not a fan of micro-transactions this game though idler needs alot of attention or money because you can't auto upgrade.
Progress doesn't seem worthwhile, the many research/skill trees are the same, the art is cookie-cutter at best.

I don't understand why there are so many different tabs that you have to click on to upgrade in order to make progress, because all of these tabs pretty much contain the same thing, extremely minor upgrades to your squads health, damage, or specific role of each individual character. You have talents, personal tree of life, guild tree of life, blessings from the oracle, firestone and meteorite upgrade trees in the library, forbidden knowledge, exotic merchant, the alchemist, this is already so many different things to click on for the same minor upgrades, and there's probably even more. All of those contain the exact same upgrades. You could have literally made a single upgrade tree containing these upgrades with a higher percentage for each node. Something about this game feels off, it really feels like it is designed in a way to make you become extremely addicted, and given that there are many different things you can pay for in order to progress, it is not something you want to become addicted to. You will hit a massive wall at some point and question if you need to pay in order to progress, because the thirty different tabs containing upgrades have small percentages that aren't impactful until upgraded 20 times, which takes forever.

The game feels like a chore though, which is why I wouldn't recommend it. Especially if you play multiple idlers at the same time.

Firestone starts out promising with polished visuals and easy idle mechanics. The early game feels smooth, but once you get deeper in, the cracks start to show.

Progress can be lost when servers or systems change, and there‚Äôs no guarantee that what you‚Äôve built will carry forward. The monetization ramps up sharply, and staying competitive often means spending heavily. Servers also cycle or merge, which resets leaderboards and forces players to start fresh with no lasting benefits. On top of that, while some players are helpful, the overall community can feel unfriendly at times and moderation doesn‚Äôt always provide the best support.

On the positive side, if you just want a casual idle experience and don‚Äôt mind ignoring competition or long-term investment, the early and mid-game can be enjoyable. But for players who care about stability, fairness, and a healthy environment, this game is difficult to recommend.

TL;DR: Firestone looks good at first but becomes a pay-to-win grind with resets, lost progress, and a less-than-welcoming community. Not recommended unless you only want short-term casual play.
